title: When will a confrontation involving the national military forces of North Korea and either South Korea, the United States, or Japan result in at least one fatality?
preds: There have been no fatal interactions between any of these parties up to date. As there is under a month left and current relations have only improved in recent months it is unlikely that one will result within the next 15 days. It is also likely that Moon Jae In will visit Pyongyang in the coming months, further improving relations (https://www.wsj.com/articles/south-korean-president-to-visit-pyongyang-in-bid-to-revive-diplomacy-1537136720). While a meeting another meeting between Trump and Kim may be on hold for now, direct and fatal violence is likely to occur even as the Singapore conference failed to yield definitive and timely results (https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/south-korea-forges-ahead-with-charm-offensive-to-kim-regime-even-as-us-outreach-cools/2018/09/15/4cd9a0ac-b691-11e8-ae4f-2c1439c96d79_story.html?utm_term=.04a36d358b7d). Japan is least likely to have confrontation as they are in a less precarious location than SK and would not risk raising tensions.

There has not been a clash resulting in one or more deaths between North Korea and either the US, South Korea, or Japan since 2010. Because of this, it's unlikely that there would suddenly be one within this month eight years after the last one. However, the possibility remains that these tensions could flare up again, though it is not very likely, especially based on the growing friendliness between North and South Korea.  https://www.theguardian.com/news/datablog/2010/nov/23/north-korea-yeonpyeong-island-incidents-map
https://www.theguardian.com/world/interactive/2010/nov/23/korea-incidents-map

Dropping the last two points and just saying no because we only have five weeks or so left.
Both sides will try to avoid incidents as their constructive dialog continues.
Updating from 0/0/0/2/98 due to passage of time and apparent current stability.
We've slid by the June dates. NK dismantling of a missile test site had probably bought another period of relative calm. And the norm here is no conflict.

No reason for North Korea to risk the progress they made with the recent summit.
It is not in the North's interest for that to occur, especially now.  As a rational player, Ug and his "team" (likely including China) will avoid escalating to a military confrontation.
I wish they'd do something soon, but it's doubtful.

Nort Korea has settled down for quite a bit now. I believe they've been struggling with economical issues, therefore they need to rethink their strategy.  I think there is no chance of fatalities during this year, hopefully not even later.
I just do not see it happening unless it is an accident.
Updating from 0/0/1/2/97 due to passage of time and continued diplomatic improvement.
Updating, also in light of US-RNK talks and forthcoming leaders' meeting in Singapore.

Peace is actually the prevailing norm here. The two biggest actors, T & K, both have a strong interest in keeping things quiet. That said, the combination of Trump and Bolton, or Kim deciding on a gambit, means we must allow some leeway for global-level brain farts.

A single fatality is almost a sure thing. It will be blamed on 'foolish bravado' or 'simply an error' depending on the side you are on.

With the general direction of more cooperation between North Korea and its former enemies, I cannot foresee a reason to support any threshold for anything (even Trump, LOL) screwing this up.  As a result I would have to give this a less than a 1% chance of happening.
I don't believe there will be a military conflict at all between these countries. Especially given the fact of the new peace treaty.
I am good on what I do.

It's been several years since this actually happened, and given the warming of relations between the United States and North Korea, with the unprecedented agreement of the leaders of both nations to meet along with North Korea's alleged willingness to discuss de-nuclearization, the odds are at their lowest point in modern history. Of course, that may all change; this might just be he latest North Korean plot and one should consider the rather hawkish cabinet of the Trump administration. However, given past historical data and landmark agreements from both countries, this is as safe a bet as ever.
Negotiations will prevent conflict in short run
Both sides will be on their best behavior for a while.
No major actions will be taken until North Korea and the US meet. After that however, escalation is possible through accident or design.

Updating following the start of ROK-UK military exercises and everything continues to track towards a calm period in the lead up to the two summits. I do think raised expectations of the past two months and in the lead up to the summits will cause a harder fall for all parties involved should progress not be made in the talks.

Considering the recent development of the promise of a meeting between Kim Jong Un and Donald Trump, I think this will decrease tensions and thus lead to a lower chance of a confrontation between North Korea and it's adversaries. Using the Bayesian Updating tool my new prediction is that there will only be a 1.748 chance of a confrontation happening or in other words a 98.252 chance that a confrontation will not occur before 1 October 2018
We'll be looking for the standard false flag to get this one started. There are supposed to be 21 million people in N. Korea. I'm afraid there are less than 5.

Tensions are falling as Kim Jung Un continues to outplay the President of the USA. With China's backing and South Korea's search for diplomatic entanglement, NoKo has nothing to gain by increasing military tension.

summit turns on the charm offensive and cuts the chance of war.
Outlook has changed with Bolton. We will be much more aggressive, and unconcerned about collateral damage.

There is too much diplomatic momentum with or without John Bolton. It is likely Bolton's appointment could be challenged by clearance issues.  Additionally I don't think his hawkish tendencies will be embraced by anyone in the administration especially Pompao who, after this administration, wants to live to fight another day and exit with a viable political future intact.
   Bolton's abradive temperament and arrogance ultimately will not sit well with Trump or anyone else in the administration. I don't think he will have enough influence too aggressively act against North Korea.
It's 26 March, so first two are zero and near zero.  Beyond that as U.S. election grows closer probability that something will happen steadily increases (October surprise theory of U.S. politics).

Updating as the 1 Jan-31 March period closes.  I remain concerned about the ROK-UK military exercises that will kick off 1 Apr. The exercises could become a convenient excuse to upend talks with Moon and Trump and if those talks fail I think the raised expectations of the past two months will cause a harder fall for all parties involved.
Adjusting towards more sanguine figures given the latest diplomatic efforts of approach between the USA and NK.

March 1 has already passed. March 31 is almost at hand, and there is no activity yet. I don't think there will be any escalation before President Trump is able to schedule a meeting with Kim Jong-un. I also think there is no chance of any South Korean casualties before a stronger action occurs; those two countries will unify before December 31, 2020.

North Korea's belligerence rises toward a peak around September, when the US and South Korea prepare for their annual military defense exercises, which North Korea chooses to regard as an imminent threat. Under the Trump administration, management of the contrived crisis relationship has been erratic and unpredictable, and Tillerson's departure has exacerbated this. Similar periods of uncertainty have resulted in armed exchanges and fatalities in the past.
The longer N.Korea stays isolated and sanctioned, the riskier it will become. If you want to make peace talks, get to action.

Although relations between the United States and North Korea have flared in the past months, there important wildcard is the ongoing relations between North and South Korea. Providing Kim Jong Un can maintain positive relations with President Moon, the likelihood that the Koreas, the US, or Japan would get involved with a conflict is highly unlikely.

a lot saber rattling but little real action
The "deal" may unravel, but not so quickly. Kim is playing the long game, and is playing Trump like a fiddle.
A violent event is likely to occur after the Presidential summit if it goes poorly.
There have always been period incidents usually iniatiated by the DPRK.  You can never rule them out in any given year.
The meeting in May could result in a misunderstanding. Just sayin'.

Remember it took Trump five minutes to hang up on the Australian PM, and he apparently liked that guy. if they do meet, I can't imagine two people more likely to piss each other off.
Kim/Moon summit scheduled for late April, Kim/Trump meeting for late May. NK is making nice now. Would need several rounds of escalation and talks going wrong before it came to open battle.
Kim is buying time to work on range and reliability. He has nothing now. That's why the fake "peace" talk.

Trump and Kim slated to "talk" in the next few weeks, so will likely be on good behavior post-Olympics/pre-talk. A lot will depend on how the talks go, but DPRK may be trying to use this meeting as a legitimizing force and photo op with a US President. Confrontation with DPRK is cyclical and I think we're out of the sabre rattling, at least for now. This could, of course, change with the unpredictability of Trump and the outcome of unprecedented talks.

Updated forecast (9 March) in light of KJU-Trump meeting announcement. A couple of overarching thoughts went into my forecast:
- I am taking the word "fatality" literally...i am not accounting for abductions, arrests, or detentions. If no lethal force was used it is not a fatality opportunity.
- I think of every exchange of fire in the historic record as an equal "opportunity" for a fatality. So I didn't really care if somebody died or not, I just cared if somebody was willing enough to pull a trigger/use lethal force against the other side.
- I think we are in a "high tension" year a la 1994, 1996, 2002, and 2010 leading me to plus up the overall likelihood of a fatality in line with what occurred those years compared to average or non-tension years. In all but 1994, there were standoffs that either resulted in fatalities or significant fatality opportunities that occurred prior to October. On average the bulk of fatality opportunities occur outside the first quarter of the calendar year. With an impending meeting between KJU and Trump to occur by May I think the probabilities are even lower.  The hard bit is the second quarter of the calendar year (1 April - 30 June). The KJU-Trump visit will occur right in the middle of it. Prior to the visit I do think the probabilities for a fatality are minimal (think something accidental). After the meeting however, there is the potential for raised expectations of a solution or detente leading to disappointment as well as the always dangerous Blue Crab fishing season in the West Sea. Will have to wait and see how the KJU-Trump meeting goes. If it goes badly, this probability will rise. If it goes well, it will decrease substantially. Third quarter factors are the thought that the raised expectations being disappointed factor would likely have occurred by then and the start of the late summer/early fall US-ROK military series of exercises being something that would dampen the environment for fatality opportunities. Should the KJU-Trump meeting go well, I will substantially reduce this probability. Biggest concerns/weaknesses of my forecast:
- Weighting all use of lethal force the same. There are clearly differing degrees of lethal force that may or may not lead to an actual fatality, e.g. DMZ border firings are not necessarily aiming to kill but just to warn. There just isn't sufficient detail in the reports to tell which ones were more lethal than the others so I preferred to weight them equally.
Shifting my predictions to later in the year due to passage of time.

Recent summit probably means March will be quiet. Odds of a clash will rise sharply if follow-on talks get derailed by hostile rhetoric or actions from Pyongyang or Washington (Seoul is the pacifist here). Nonetheless I suspect the North Koreans will be leery of provoking Trump; a side benefit of his unpredictability.
With current news being about peace talks between North and South Korea, I believe the chance of this occurring to be 1%.
This has happen before, sinking of the South Korean Navy Ship, shelling of the NW islands, fishing boats, ect, ect. .....

War games with the US & South Korea will probably in April or May 2018. This increases risk of actual confrontation with North Korea. Additionally since 2017, troops, & equipment has been increasingly positioned in the region. This indicates a certain readiness for a confrontation should it occur by either side.

I would not expect any casualties to occur unless nK launches another missile with a nuclear warhead attached or the US suspects they have developed the ability to do so.  Before this occurs I expect to see additional missile launches and another nuclear test.  Neither of these events seem to be imminent.

Updating my previous forecast to reflect the aforementioned correlation between the increasing temperature/tension relationship, and the heightened chance of DPRK entering a period of dormancy due to global political/economic  instability. The relationship  with China is strained as Xi Jinping  courts capitalism and military buildup. That relationship is being usurped by Russia, while dialog is opening for reconciliation with the South.

I don't think this is going to be pretty analysis on my part and I know a lot of people are going to disagree with me including my husband "the pro".
   The base line on this analysis is soft and maybe a little different, but here goes.
 It is evident since our president first achieved a high political profile and whose voice consistently came onto the national stage that he creates conflict and chaos to blow a situation up then relies on his loyal aides to clean it up with some sort of momentary policy or spin band aid. He comes into conflict with everyone and is incapable of getting along with anyone. His reaction to problematic situations of any sort is to lash out destructively at family, staff, other world leaders, etc. The North Korean issue is certainly not immune to this dynamic and will only get worse in the future as this sort of situation precludes formation of a realistic responsible policy towards anything.
 Several things are happening now that are unsettling and it appears as though they will continue to destabilize our relationship North Korea, South Korea and China.
    The very possible resignation of HR McMaster who will more likely than not be replaced by a loyalist or a John Bolton type of hawk.
     John Kelly's weakened position as chief of staff as he tries to shore up a White House that is coming unraveled as he goes up against the president's closest aides and his family. The Mueller investigation will only add to the uncertainty and exacerbate the chaos.
       The failure to appoint the South Korean pick for Ambassador due to their reticence for military intervention in North Korea. I know people I have spoken to who are professionals have brushed off this military "bloody nose" threat as bluster however with recent diplomatic developments this seems to be taking on a very ominus tone.The most subtly alarming development; the resignation of Joseph Yum.

    Also, the US continues implement a my way or the highway position on North Korea abandoning its nukes in order to begin diplomatic talks
"We are sorry to see him retire but our diplomatic efforts regarding North Korea will continue based on our maximum pressure campaign to isolate the DPRK until it agrees to begin credible talks toward a denuclearized Korean peninsula.” https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/27/joseph-yun-us-north-korea-diplomat
True there are checks and balances in place but with the level of chaos, lack of policy and isolated Department secretaries I see a  distinct potential for conflict.
   New sanctions against North Korea will involve aggressive maritime actions to enforce sanctions thus making the potential for conflict and resulting fatalities more likely. Historically in the past 15 to 18 years the vast majority of conflicts and fatalities have happened in a maritime environment. The United States Coast Guard will be used to enforce the sanctions they are not necessarily considered a military force however this is a very thin and fragile line and certainly not enough to prevent open conflict or retaliation.
There have been low level skirmishes since the armistice and fatalities among those forces are not unexpected.
To much to loose both on north Korea’s part and for South Korea, Japan and U.S.
He is very unlikely to loose power.
I do not believe that a confrontation like this will happen, as I expect North and South Korea to become (gradually and slowly) closer (based on recent happenings).
US will stir things up so it escalates before election
US will stir things up so it escalates before election

If N.Korea (Kim Jong-Un) and the U.S.(Trump) meet for talks, China (Xi Jinping) will be needed as a cultural mediator as well as mentor to Kim Jong-Un. Add South Korea to the mix and 3/4 of the worlds power is in close proximity, with their greatest assets (leadership) on the line. Cooperation amongst nations can bring on feelings of betrayal/deception. Expect set-ups that would pit these countries against each other/set off a nuclear war.

Tensions with the international community and North Korea are cooling down as they seem to have suspended their nuclear tests, and their willingness to negotiate is becoming more apparent. There was supposed to be a "negotiation" between VP Pence and two high level North Korean officials while Pence was in Asia, but it was cancelled two hours prior to the meeting due to Pence's hardline rhetoric regarding the issue. North Korea has also apparently expressed its desire to talk with the US and South Korea, according to South Korea. This negotiation factor aside, North Korea knows that it would be overwhelmingly defeated in conflict with these nations, and will not continue to provoke us to the point where we need to attack them, and we will not engage them first as long as we are not provoked.
The outcome of a response to an ICBM / Bomb test.

They all have too much too lose and are basically located in the same area, unless North Korea doesn't care about their native ancestral lands, waters, people and history  (their culture). If North Korea has nothing to lose (more to gain), orchestrating tensions in highly disputed waters and then relying on Russian defense/loyalty is exactly what they'll do. North Korean influence seems to strengthen as US/China/Middle Eastern relations weaken.

Because I do not believe N. Kroea intends invading or attacking other nations militarily. I believe there is a very minor risk of fatality due to border skirmishes or other border related military activity

Korean confrontations are likely but escapees over the DMZ should not count in general.  A conflict within the DMZ could become an issue, and causalities have happened in the past.  The current pressure on North Korea offers an opportunity for powder keg conditions to ignite.  With the final closing ceremony for the Winter Olympics, conflict is resurfacing in the springtime.  There might be real tensions by summer, but the approach of winter will curtail it.
N Korea currently appears to be in a conciliatory position.  Trump is likely to continue provoking them. But no serious military action will occur in the foreseeable future.
Updated forecast: I believe there is only approximately a 2% chance that there will be a confrontation before October 1 2018
It is likely that if conflict occurs it will not happen until after the Olympics are over. If relations continue on their current track conflict will likely happen before the summer is over.
N Korea is bluffing, to get a spot on the world stage, and to give the leadership a position of godlike authority among N Korean People.

In the past decade there have only been several exchanges of fire, either on land or on sea, but only a few that resulted in one or more deaths, the last ones in 2010. With recent developments in the context of the Olympic Games and the improvement of relationships between both Koreas, chances seem to be smaller that such incidents will happen. There is, however, always a small chance that by coincidence border incidents may take place.
Kim Jong-un isn't irrational and will seek to keep tensions manageable.

DPRK has shown the ability to initiate conventional warfare while using nuclear and ballistic missile tests as a distraction.  See for instance the Battle of Daecheong, the Battles of Yeonpyeong, and ROKS Cheonan sinking.  Furthermore, the Winter Olympics have served as a distraction and cover for military activities before (see annexation of Crimea after the Sochi Olympics in 2014.)  The joint flag at the Olympics is a distraction.  Since power is concentrated with very few people in DPRK, the probability for a personality-induced "wild card" resulting from some international slight or insult perceived by DPRK's leadership during the games is higher than normal, not lower.  DPRK leadership will want to "cash in" on the goodwill sooner rather than later.  DPRK may even intentionally expose its forces ambiguously, forcing action by SK/USA/Japan, playing the victim, and currying favor and sympathy internationally.
Things are coming to a head.

Tensions and one-upmanship have been too harsh for too long. At some point a mistake will be made. After the Olympics the pressure control valve will probably fail when hopes and expectations are short circuited. Tempers will probably be lost.

It is in the strategic interest of North Korea to minimize conflict and promote peace with South Korea, Japan, and the U.S. during the time of the Olympic Games.  With the 2018 Winter Olympics taking place in Pyeongchang, South Korea near the border of North Korea there is much speculation of an international incident. However, the governments of North and South Korea have advocated for unity during the time of the Games, and even decided to march under a singular flag. While this has resulted in many protests in South Korea, it is evident that peace is being waged for the sake of the Olympic Games. Moreover, this grants North Korea an opportunity to legitimize themselves on the global stage. What better way to combat their negative stigma than to promote peace and unity while competing in the Olympic Games taking place in their rival nation?
I believe it doesn't need to happen in general, but if so, for sure not before 1 October 2018.

The boiling point of the Korean peninsula conflict is not in sight, yet. The edge when the conflict becomes violent is near but actors are keeping away from it. The consequences of a confrontation even without fatal casualties are well known to all parties involved. Accidents can always happen, this is why all answer options have at least a probability of 1%.
I think it is unlikely during the Olympics, but the goodwill will diminisj over time.

Tensions rise with temperatures. Additionally, if the first yearly harvest does not have a high yield, the situation could foster desperation within the DPRK. That said, the overall chance that Kim Jung Un decides on a military engagement is far less likely than a move towards economic exchange at a cost of anti-war treaty with the global community.

We've had worse tension that what is currently going on.  North and South Korea seem to be warming ever so slightly considering the Olympics are coming up and Donald Trump had lessened his Korea rhetoric.

The situation has been getting more and more tense throughout last year including information on attempted nuclear weapon tests in North Korea. If this happens again it is likely countries in question will intervene resulting in casualties. However, taken lack of news on the  issue in past weeks, it is not likely it will happen in next few months.

Frequency in base rate is surprisingly high if you include data from 2017. Trend would indicate more conflict at increasing rate. Some outlying events could have a chilling effect. Outlook more short-term.
I think likelihood increases over time and more so near 4th July
Risk of fighting will be highest after the Winter Olympics have concluded.

Some kind of armed conflict appears inevitable.  I don't think US will strike immediately while numerous cards are still on the table; however, Trump, based on past and current statements, feels a responsibility to take care of the North Korea nuclear problem once-and-for-all.  He also is facing immense political pressure from investigations, which lends me to believe, combined with political preparations in the works, that a first-strike the by the United States is possible and plausible within the next 6 months.  He may want to get this done before he could possibly get thrown out of office.  The US also may commit itself to special-forces attacks that specifically target the PRK's nuclear (or ICBM) capabilities, which would also result in at least one death, inevitably.  One major wild-card I did not include in my calculations is the high plausibility that the generals and high-ups in the Pentagon are stalling for time and way-laying by any means possible an armed conflict until Trump is out of office.  I've placed greater weight on the mid-summer months based on wars being more prevalent at this time of the year.  August tends to be "war month," but I think it'll happen sooner, and the seeds of a summer problem could be sown much sooner.  Yet another reason for an earlier timetable is that the 2018 elections are coming up, and it would be politically expedient for the Republicans to take some kind of action that increases their image of strength and resolve.  People rarely choose to flip allegiances during wartime, and it would also likely take some heat off of people getting indicted.  (Yet another forecast included in this forecast...)
The leaders of North Korea will accept an offer of  $Billions to abdicate to an isolated area (Such as the the Napoleons)

Conflict is NOT beneficial for the Kim regime and regime survival is the primary incentive for KJU.
Conflict is NOT beneficial for the United States due to Chinese interference and high political costs.  The winter Olympics offers the opportunity for conflict even though Kim Jong Un has made public statements indicating his high hopes for the Olympics to bring cooperation and peace. The only reason that some weight is placed on the early part of this year is that his message could still fit into his cult narrative for re-unification if conflict did break out.

I think there is a 90% chance this will not happen before October 1st 2018 because, even though securities risk and tension have risen in recent times, I don't think any of these nations have anything to gain from involving themselves in a confrontation in the near future. Also, with the Olympics coming up it may temporarily ease tensions.

It is an untenable risk to the Hawks in the U.S government to allow N. Korea to have the ability to cause the deaths of 100k or more American civilians with relative ease.  The probability of the Republicans loosing control of the House increases the difficulty of having the U.S government act decisively during a conflict.   The fact that the human and capital losses will be horrific for U.S allies will be rationalized by the argument that at least those losses were not in the sovereign territory of the United States of America.

South Korean preparations after the Cheonanham warship sinking and the Yangpyeondo shelling mean North Korea is more effectively deterred. Also, North Korea tends to find novel ways of applying pressure to complicate retaliation. North Korea used violence twice in 2011 and is now much riskier. And the North has little incentive to alienate the Moon Administration, as it likely sees it as preferable to a conservative government. Trump Administration may be looking for an excuse to give North Korea a “bloody nose”, further deterring North Korea from using low level force. South Korea is very unlikely to initiate violence based on past behavior. Despite Trump administration’s threatening posture, it will also be likely be deterred from using force by the risk of escalation. Japan is very unlikely to initiate violence, but North Korea may target Japan as it may perceive that the risk of retaliation is lower than if it uses violence against the US or South Korea. An incident during the Olympics early in the year is very unlikely with the North’s agreement to participate. Risk rises later in the year as more potential for unforeseen developments.

There has been ongoing talking discussing the situation with South Korea and the United States about continuing joint military exercises after the conclusion of the Olympics.  Even though North and South Korea have agreed to terms on participating together in several Olympic events, the escalation of joint training exercises could increase tensions between the countries after the Olympics conclude.  https://www.cnn.com/2018/01/26/asia/us-south-korea-military-exercises-olympics/index.html
I feel this could potentially increase the chances of a fatality occurrig after the Olympics simply because tensions will rise and relationship building will deteriorate after the Olympics.

Tensions between the North and the South have risen, which was well documented after the election of Donald Trump with more nuclear tests. However, it is important to note that North and South Korea have agreed to hold high level talks and are planning on competing under the same flag in the next winter Olympics in Pyeongchang. The governments of the two also hope to use this time to hold high levels talks especially on easing military tensions. However, there is still suspicion that the North will use the talks only for cover and continue developing their military capabilities.   https://www.ft.com/content/7fe629fa-fb9a-11e7-9b32-d7d59aace167 https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/10/world/asia/moon-jae-in-trump-north-korea.html?mtrref=www.google.com&gwh=77C2523244CA1C8232F81EC852445422&gwt=pay

A lot of rhetoric and empty threats here, US just got out of a war so getting back into one may be an unpopular decision without a good reason and IF N Korea is smart they won't give the US a reason  And of course no one wants to be the reason that the world goes into a nuclear war

I believe N. Korea will engage in either a direct attack or a terrorist event around the upcoming Olympics resulting in at least one casualty. His withdrawal from the games should be taken as a red flag, in my opinion.

DMZ and border defections and rescue may result in at least 1 fatality

This week, I decided to take on the question of “when will a confrontation involving the national military forces of North Korea and either South Korea, the United States, or Japan results in at least one fatality?”  I believe there is 0% chance that any confrontation will result in at least one fatality before 1 July 2018.  In the following 3 months, I believe there is 1% chance that a confrontation will result in at least one fatality before 30 September 2018.  Lastly, I believe there is a 99% chance that a confrontation will result in at least one fatality on 1 October 2018 or later.  I base this assumption on the fact that North Korea and South Korea have made some progress in negotiations in the past few months.  They will walk as one unified country during the opening ceremony of the Winter Olympics next month, which was highly improbable up until recently.  Japan and the United States are interested in peaceful negotiation on the Korean Peninsula, thus they do not want to engage North Korea militarily; however, North Korea and its unstable dictator can at any moment change his mind and take military action that will result in casualties.

Military confrontations between the DPRK and ROK happen relatively regularly and there are usually a small number of casualties. A recent exception (to the "small number") is the Cheonan Incident in 2010 where 46 South Korean sailors were killed in a confrontation off the western coast. Also, in 2015, several South Korean solders were killed in the DMZ by recently laid land mines. Kim uses these, evidently, both to test South Korean defenses as well as for internal political reasons.  Between 1 Jan and 31 March a conflict is less likely because of PyeongChang Olympics in which DPRK athletes are participating. Also I've kept the percentages low in the near term because the DPRK appears to be driving a "sunshine wedge" between the South and the US, although these efforts (cf Kim Dae-Jung's) are historically short-lived. However, as it becomes clear to Kim in the second part of the year that the alliance is not weakening the probabilities increase.  The last choice should be reworded to "definitely after October 2018"  -- current wording is confusing.

A couple of overarching thoughts went into my forecast:
- I am taking the word "fatality" literally...i am not accounting for abductions, arrests, or detentions. If no lethal force was used it is not a fatality opportunity.
- I think of every exchange of fire in the historic record as an equal "opportunity" for a fatality. So I didn't really care if somebody died or not, I just cared if somebody was willing enough to pull a trigger/use lethal force against the other side.
- I think we are in a "high tension" year a la 1994, 1996, 2002, and 2010 leading me to plus up the overall likelihood of a fatality in line with what occurred those years compared to average or non-tension years. In all but 1994, there were standoffs that either resulted in fatalities or significant fatality opportunities that occurred prior to October. On average the bulk of fatality opportunities occur outside the first quarter of the calendar year. I weighted the first quarter even lower than the historic average due to the Winter Olympics this year as well as the high probability that ROK-DPRK talks will occur soon after. Despite the historical instance of a military confrontation occurring during the 2002 World Cup I think the political pressure will be on for the North and South not to instigate anything during this period.  I increased the probability for the second quarter over the high tension season average by what I decreased from the first quarter due to the fear of raised expectations for a solution or detente to occur leading to disappointment coinciding with the resumption of postponed spring US-ROK exercises (re-start dates have no yet been announced) as well as the start of the Blue Crab fishing season in the West Sea.  Third quarter factors are the thought that the raised expectations being disappointed factor would likely have occurred by then and the start of the late summer/early fall US-ROK military series of exercises being something that would dampen the environment for fatality opportunities. Biggest concerns/weaknesses of my forecast:
- Heavy weight given to the dampening effect of the Winter Olympics (no real historic comparison). This is largely a "gut"/experience call which I know is discouraged.
- Weighting all use of lethal force the same. There are clearly differing degrees of lethal force that may or may not lead to an actual fatality, e.g. DMZ border firings are not necessarily aiming to kill but just to warn. There just isn't sufficient detail in the reports to tell which ones were more lethal than the others so I preferred to weight them equally. By the way...how fun is this?!?!?

I'm taking mwokash's rates as the base, but I'll update and augment according to what I've seen so far. My guess is that there is likely to be some sort of military response within the next few weeks, based on the timing of past incidents to coincide with Chinese diplomatic initiatives or US exercises. I also put the odds slightly higher for that same period because traditionally there have been more US-SK joint exercises around February-March for the last couple of years, which I would think increases the general risk of some retaliatory action. Again, it doesn't mean fatalities but with an increased show of force, the likelihood of an incident increases and then the likelihood of fatalities or injuries.

The lessons of the Ace tournament for OSINT as summarized by Jason Matheny Director of DIARPA
at https://www.thecipherbrief.com/column/agenda-setter/use-whats-known-get-unknowns
"Jason Matheny: There has been some empirical investigation on the relative value of classified and unclassified analysis. Measuring cost per unit citation in intelligence products, including things like the presidential daily briefing found that per citation, open source intelligence was less than one-tenth the cost. This was an unclassified result. We have done some work here at IARPA looking at the relative accuracy of open source and classified intelligence, including as part of a program called “Ace” that we ran here, in which you had people who lacked clearances, who made judgments about the same questions that were also posed to people who had clearances. And on most events, the difference in accuracy wasn’t significant. But there was a subset of events for which the differences in accuracy were significant and where classified information seems to make a big difference. Broader topics, things like how political elections would turn out, or whether there would be civil unrest, whether there would be disease outbreaks – those were the kinds of questions where unclassified information was often quite relevant. Same was also true for economic forecasts. So these forecasts about events where information is already pretty widely distributed, in which there are multiple observers and multiple participants – things such as for political elections, economic events, epidemics and science and technology – all of those were cases are where unclassified information was highly accurate, at least when aggregated in ways that were empirically well founded. Think of the other category of events, where you don’t have many participants, you don’t have lots of observable data [and] there aren’t unclassified or open source datasets that are highly relevant. That includes topics like weapons tests or leadership decisions in countries that have tightly controlled information. I think one of the best things to look at is the head-to-head comparisons of unclassified versus classified information, and how accurate judgments are based on either sets of information." So I note that Forecasting on questions like this certainly  adds value for all.
But statistically on average OSINT alone is not enough for these categories of questions Mr. Matheny is a lot brighter and experienced and resourced than me. no comparison.
but I think the counter-argument can be made that in closed systems like
DPRK, OSINT analysis may be as, or more reliable

see http://www.38north.org/2017/10/udmh102517/ "Among these, the one of greatest interest is the July 27 Factory (a.k.a., Aoji-ri Chemical Complex or 7.27 Factory) located in the northeast (42.522437, 130.349402), adjacent to the town of Kyonghung (formerly Undok).[10] During 2003, a defector, Yi Pok Ku, who worked in the North’s missile program, stated that the factory was built during the 1970s and is subordinate to the Second Economic Committee to produce chemical weapons. Yi further describes the facility as “…a factory which synthesizes propulsion fuel for ballistic missiles” and that Dr. Yi Sung Ki—the “father” of North Korea’s nuclear and ballistic missile programs, and the inventor of vinalon—took an active role in the factory’s development and operations as an early director of the Academy of Defense Sciences.[11] Yi Pok Ku’s account does not provide greater details about the type of “fuel for ballistic missiles” being produced, but it is clear from the timing that it was too early to be UDMH for the chronological reasons noted above. He was likely conflating production of AK-20K/TG-02 with later production of other fuels for the P-15 (SS-N-2 styx) anti-ship cruise missile,[12] which uses these propellants and was then in domestic production.[13] During the past five years, a number of infrastructure changes have occurred within the July 27 Factory, although it is unclear whether these are related to the national-level chemical industry modernization program noted above. It stands to reason that a factory designed and built to produce dangerous chemical weapons and highly toxic and corrosive missile fuel, and is still in operation, would be a strong candidate for the production of UDMH. Finally, there has long been a close relationship between the July 27 Factory and nearby July 21 Factory (a.k.a., 7.21 Factory or Kyonghung Explosives Plant), located 1.5 kilometers to the northeast (42.534961° 130.361007°), which produces explosives and chemicals used in the manufacture of explosives (e.g., ammonia, etc.), and maintains an extensive storage facility. Whether this relationship extends to potential UDMH production (e.g., sharing of scientists and technicians, supply of chemicals, provision of storage, etc.) is unclear." Figure 1. The July 27 Factory and nearby July 1 Factory."

------ ======   Update Note (11-15-2017)  =====-----
There is some fun "Bayesian" math that I didn't consider during in my initial forecast.  By that I mean while the probability of an incident occurring during the year is 61%, in those years where multiple do occur, the question would be resolved with the first incident.  This should more heavily weight the initial quarters than the later quarters.   Running a monte-carlo that sets the average annual probability of an incident =41% distributes the weights slightly differently.

This question leaves two important conditions up in the air:
1) Do Civilian Abductions Count?
2) Does the capture/killing of Spies/defectors count?
--- Would love clarity on this because it significantly changes the probabilities.  At the moment I assume they do. ------ ======   Summary of Approach =====----- First step was to get the baseline probability of loss of life due to strife between North & South.   To do this, I went through all the interactions between the North & South since 1980.  The results were pretty grim. Probability of at least 1 incident where life was lost (38 total incidents): 1980's) 80% 
1990's) 60%
2000's) 60%
2010's) 43% Average Annual Probability: 61% Here's the wrinkle:  Even though tensions are really high at the moment, the probability of incident is lower in the recent years than in the past decades.  While I could be "fooled by randomness" in this regard, I suspect it is probably deliberate.  Thus, I'm taking a slightly lower than average probability than history would suggest, and closer to the 2010's probability (47%).  Note that since we are not forecasting a full year, this equates to a 41% remaining probability. As far as the distribution of incidents over the year.   Incidents by Quarter:
First Quarter: 8
Second Quarter: 7
Third Quarter: 9
Fourth Quarter: 14 While there are more during the 4th quarter, it does not meet the statistical threshold.  As such, the daily probability based on a 47% annual probability is:  0.13% Spreading this probability over the relevant dates for the question results in my forecast Hope this helps. Sources: 
https://fas.org/sgp/crs/row/RL30004.pdf

 Chinese President Xi Jinping will send a special envoy to North Korea this week, the countries' state media reported Wednesday, amid strained ties over Pyongyang's nuclear and missile programs. The trip to Pyongyang on Friday by Song Tao, the head of the international department at the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China (CPC), comes one week after Xi and U.S. President Donald Trump held a summit in Beijing last Thursday. The report said that Song will inform North Korea of the results of China's recent party congress, in which Xi cemented his power as he entered his second five-year term. North Korea's state news agency said in a short dispatch that Song will visit the North "soon," without revealing details. Trump finished his 13-day tour of Asia Tuesday, which included stops in South Korea and China. Trump has said that China should do more to rein in its wayward neighbor. North Korea's ties with China, its main ally and economic benefactor, have been frayed over Pyongyang's persistent advancement of its nuclear and missile programs. China has implemented U.N. sanctions on North Korea over its nuclear and missile tests. "China and North Korea will exchange opinions about issues of mutual concern including party-to-party matters and bilateral ties, along with the party congress," Geng Shuang, spokesman at China's foreign ministry, said in a briefing. Some base rate of small scale military altercations between NK and SK, although these don't cause fatalities often, somewhat heightened tensions increase this possibility. Very low likelihood of more significant conflict involving other actors.

The US, Japan, and South Korea all have indicated they are wary of paying the steep price necessary of a war with the DPRK. They are unlikely to strike first, and even if they wanted to, neither of the three countries' elite have the political appetite for a new, costly, long war with a Chinese proxy. 
If hostilities do break out, they are much more likely to be triggered by the DPRK. What would need to happen in order for the DPRK to feel the need to violently confront Japan, the US, or South Korea? 
The North Koreans would need to feel so insecure that they would calculate that provoking any or all three of these countries, and risking retaliation would be worth the the initial aggression. These actions take place in the wider context of the American and Japanese governments. Both Trump and Abe have emphasized military force, with Abe attempting to inch his country away from post-WW2 pacifism. The North Koreans, for all their rhetoric, are rational actors that point to the fall of Saddam and Ghaddafi as evidence that rogue regimes need nukes to survive. In order for them to risk provoking the US, Japan, or South Korea, they would need to be in a position of strength to feel confident about their own regime's survival. Only a nuclear missile capable (which many sources state that the North Koreans are about a year away from producing) of hitting the US would provide them with sufficient security and self-confidence to ratchet up tensions in this way. This is why my forecast is set at 4% around mid-year 2018. However, there is the possibility that the North Koreans miscalculate and misjudge the nature of a military exercise, or have incorrect intelligence about military movements near them. They may also take news reports of 'decapitation raids' on their leadership seriously and might--during a time of heightened tensions--misjudge flights, border movements, etc, as advance warning of a raid. This could also trigger fatal conflict. The Koreans do not have the modern battlefield experience required to save injured soldiers and are most likely to lose a soldier in such a confrontation. There is also the possibility that a civilian is accidentally or intentionally killed near the border. However, such events are rare.

NK doesn't want to provoke the U.S. by drawing first blood. There's news reports that NK wants to finish establishing its nuclear weapons program before entering negotiations so it has leverage. While I acknowledge that a civilian casualty could occur from, say, a test ICBM falling on a fishing vessel, it's not likely to be the desired outcome of NK. Therefore, NK is unlikely to attempt a confrontation with South Korea, the US, or Japan.
